title: Synthetic Recap
body:
WASHINGTON – On a night where defenses reigned supreme, one man authored a historic offensive masterpiece. Karl Malone, "The Mailman," delivered in the clutch, but the Washington Wizards found just enough to steal the victory from the jaws of his monumental performance.

In a grinding, physical battle that ended 88-86, Malone was a force of nature, pouring in a staggering **43 points** for the Utah Jazz. While his teammates struggled to find their rhythm, Malone was relentless, attacking the rim with his signature power and hitting from mid-range. His heroic effort single-handedly kept the Jazz competitive in a game where every possession was a war of attrition.

Washington’s victory was a testament to collective grit. Juwan Howard led the Wizards with a solid 20 points, while Calbert Cheaney and Tracy Murray provided crucial secondary scoring with 17 and 15 points, respectively. Their balanced attack, though overshadowed by Malone's singular brilliance, proved just enough.

The final moments were a microcosm of the entire contest. With the game on the line, Malone, who had carried his team all night, was inevitably the focal point. But the Wizards’ defense, exhausted from trying to contain him for 48 minutes, made one final stand, getting a crucial stop to preserve the narrow two-point margin.

Ultimately, the story of this game is one of a legendary individual effort that fell just short. Karl Malone’s 43 points will be remembered as a titanic performance in a losing cause, a night where one superstar almost conquered five, only to be denied at the final moment by a resilient team effort from the Washington Wizards.
